subject: Re: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
msgSnippet: ... That was my impression as well.  That is why I asked what JVM he was using.  If it is old, that may explain it.... ... -- They that give up essential
messageBody:
Jeff Nielsen wrote:
> This output is correct: testLocalByteBehavior() and
> testStaticByteBehavior() are supposed to pass, and testByteMaxValue()
> and testShortMaxValue() should fail.
>
> It is my understanding that the OP has all four of these tests passing
> in his setup.

That was my impression as well. That is why I asked what JVM he was
using. If it is old, that may explain it....


>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Mark Meyers" <markm@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, February 19, 2002 10:55 AM
> Subject: RE: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
>
>
>
>>>From: Berin Loritsch
>>>
>>>Here are my results (JDK 1.3.1)
>>>
>>>. Local Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
>>>. Static Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
>>>. Class Byte: Success means that -128 > 127
>>>F. Class Short: Success means that -32768 > 32767
>>>F
>>>Time: 0.081
>>>There were 2 failures:
>>>1)
>>>
>>>
> testByteMaxValue(StrangeByteTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
>
>>> at
>>>
> StrangeByteTest.testByteMaxValue(StrangeByteTest.java:51)
>
>>>2)
>>>
>>>
> testShortMaxValue(StrangeByteTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
>
>>> at
>>>
> StrangeByteTest.testShortMaxValue(StrangeByteTest.java:62)
>
>>>FAILURES!!!
>>>Tests run: 4, Failures: 2, Errors: 0
>>>
>>>Question:
>>>
>>>What JDK are you running? It appears you have some implicit
>>>
> upcasting
>
>>>to a long or something happening.
>>>
>>>
>>Apart from elapsed time exactly the sam output for me.
>>BUT THAT ACTUALLY MEANS THE TEST HAS PASSED (shouting out of shear
>>
> horror,
>
>>sorry ;-)
>>I use jdk 1.3.1 and JUnit 3.7 (although JUnit isn't the problem I
>>
> guess)
